snippet: The study was the first to look at segregation as a factor in lung cancer mortality, and its authors said they could not fully explain why it worsens the odds of survival for African-Americans.
abstract: Study in JAMA Surgery finds that African-Americans who live in highly segregated counties are more likely to die from lung cancer than those in counties that are less segregated.
lead_paragraph: The study was the first to look at segregation as a factor in lung cancer mortality, and its authors said they could not fully explain why it worsens the odds of survival for African-Americans.

headline.seo: Study Links Segregation and Lung Cancer Deaths in Blacks
headline.main: Segregation Linked in Study With Lung Cancer Deaths
headline.print_headline: Segregation Linked in Study With Lung Cancer Deaths
